## Document Navigator Demo
This shows how the Navigator component can be used for any type of content - here with research documents for an interdisciplinary study on high school dropout.
Vertical.Navigator:
- id: psych_motivation title: Psychological Factors in School Dropout subtitle: Psychology Research description: Comprehensive study examining motivation, self-efficacy, and psychological barriers to academic success. details: discipline: Psychology authors: [Smith, J., Johnson, M.] year: 2023 methodology: Mixed methods sampleSize: 847 students keyFindings: [Self-efficacy strongly predicts retention, Peer support reduces dropout risk, Academic identity formation crucial]
- id: socio_determinants title: Social Determinants of Educational Outcomes subtitle: Sociology Research description: Analysis of how family structure, socioeconomic status, and community factors influence educational attainment. details: discipline: Sociology authors: [Rodriguez, C., Williams, K.] year: 2022 methodology: Longitudinal cohort study sampleSize: 1,200 families keyFindings: [Family income strongly correlates with completion, Single-parent households face additional challenges, Community resources matter]
- id: econ_cost_benefit title: Economic Analysis of Dropout Prevention subtitle: Economics Research description: Cost-benefit analysis of various intervention programs and their long-term economic impacts. details: discipline: Economics authors: [Chen, L., Thompson, R.] year: 2023 methodology: Econometric analysis dataSource: State education department keyFindings: [Early intervention most cost-effective, $7 ROI for every $1 invested, Vocational programs show promise]
- id: policy_interventions title: Policy Interventions and Implementation subtitle: Public Policy Research description: Evaluation of state and federal policies aimed at reducing dropout rates and improving graduation outcomes. details: discipline: Public Policy authors: [Davis, A., Martinez, S.] year: 2022 methodology: Policy analysis scope: 15 states keyFindings: [Mandatory attendance laws have mixed results, Flexible scheduling improves outcomes, Teacher training crucial]
